completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: We'll hear argument next in Case 15­5040, Williams v. Pennsylvania. Mr. Lev.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: Due process does not allow a district attorney to make the decision to seek the death penalty against the defendant, and then in the same case become a judge of the conduct of the prosecutor who carried out that decision and obtained that result. In this case, at ­­ when he was district attorney, Chief Justice Castille made a discretionary individualized decision based upon a review of the facts that in his view, death was the appropriate sentence to seek.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Does that make a difference, the nature of his decision? Let's say he had a policy. He says, I think every case in which a defendant is convicted of first degree murder, that we ought to seek the death penalty and leave it to the jury. Maybe the jury will agree or not, but I'm going to seek the death penalty in every case where there's a conviction of first degree murder. Would you have the same recusal problem?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: I think there would be, yes, because that policy itself would be a decision that he makes. Pennsylvania law gives the district attorney ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Oh, no, I know that, but it's a categorical decision. In other words, he doesn't look at the particulars of that case. He has a policy that he's adopted ­­ you know, whether you think it's a good policy or not ­­ that doesn't depend upon the particular facts, simply on the facts of what the conviction is.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: That would still raise due process concerns, because that policy would have led to a major decision within the adversary process.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: Well, what if the case was simply in the office and he had supervisory responsibility over everything that occurs in the office, but it's a big office. If a question arose, somebody could bring it to him, but there isn't any indication of personal involvement. Would that be enough?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: Supervisory authority might be enough, depending upon the issue. When the issue goes directly towards the conduct of the prosecutions in his office, it implicates the integrity of the office and the reputation of the leadership.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: You see, the problem ­­

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: ­­ that narrow circumstance ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: Yeah. The problem that ­­ that is presented by this case is not ­­ is where this constitutional line is going to be drawn. You want us to get into ­­ get pretty deeply into the issue of a constitutional recusal policy for judges. So it's really not enough to just say what happened here was bad. Let's assume that ­­ that that is the case. Assume for the sake of argument ­­ I'm not saying one way or the other ­­ but how far does this go? And that's what I'm ­­ that's what I'm interested in. So supervisory authority would be enough, you said, but it depends on the issue? Why would it depend on the issue?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: Because the issue is directly related to that supervisory authority.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Well, what ­­ what is the rule, then, that you're formulating, so that we can answer Justice Alito's questions and similar questions? Recusal is required when, and fill in the blank.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: When the prosecutor has direct personal involvement in a substantial decision in the case, and the issue before the court reflects upon that decision.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: I ­­ I thought that your ­­ your particular position was that a judge cannot sit on any case where, as the district attorney, he signed on to the death penalty.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: That would be, Your Honor, an appropriate decision, an appropriate due process rule for this Court to reach, but it's not a rule you need to reach in this case.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: Well, what short of that is? I thought ­­ I thought critical element is, he was the district attorney, he signed off on the death penalty; some 20 odd years later, he ­­ he's a judge, he cannot sit on that case. I thought that was your position.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: Our ­­ our case takes that, but also looks at the other circumstances of the case. That includes the nature of the issue.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: But that's the ­­ that's the line­drawing problem. Why does it matter that it's the death penalty? What if it was not a capital case, but he ­­ he signed the indictment?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: I think the death penalty only matters for Eighth Amendment purposes. If it was not a capital case, if he had direct personal participation in the case and faced an issue that was related to that level of participation, that ­­ that involvement that he had, that would still be a due process ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: What if he signed the indictment?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: I'm sorry?

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: He signed the indictment. Let's say the ­­ the former ­­ the then­prosecutor signed the indictment, and there are thousands of indictments in a county like Philadelphia, so ­­

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: That ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: That would be enough?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: No. The signing of the indictment would not enough. But if his assistants came to him and said we don't know if we have enough evidence to charge this person with this crime, what do you think? And he said I've reviewed the facts, and there's enough to charge, go ahead. That would be the direct personal involvement as opposed to the ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: You're saying that the signature would not be enough because that could be pro forma? Is that what you're saying?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: What if you had a situation where he was directly involved in a matter that had nothing to do with the issue that came up later? You know, he ­­ the ­­ the assistant comes in and says we've got a real question here, you know, he wants a third extension of the trial date and should we oppose it or not. And he thinks about it and says, yeah, let's oppose it. And then 29 years later, there's an issue about a ­­ you know, a Brady violation. Is he recused from sitting on that Brady violation case?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: If ­­ if the decision he's made was only about some procedural matter that had no substantive relationship to the crime, then that would certainly be a much weaker court. And in the absence of any other circumstances ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Can you give me ­­ can you give me ­­ much weaker? Can you give me a yes­or­no on my hypothetical?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: I would say no. In the absence of any other circumstances, that would not be a due process case.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Under that answer, then, why doesn't the Brady violation problem drop out of the case? And that's not an argument for ­­ for ­­ an extra argument for recusal.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: Because I think in this case the Brady violation goes directly to his role in making the decision. This is a Brady violation about sentencing, and it relates to the decision he made to seek the death penalty. And in addition, it goes to his essential role as the chief prosecutor.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Well, he didn't know about the Brady violation. The Brady violation basically occurred in ­­ in the course of trial.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: He ­­ the ­­ the record ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: I mean after they sought the death penalty.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: That ­­ that's correct. The record doesn't show that he had any personal knowledge of the Brady violation at the time, but ­­ but a substantial Brady violation certainly calls into question the integrity of the office as a whole, and not just the individual ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Well, then, that doesn't follow with the rule that you gave me at the outset. You should recuse yourself when, and now ­­ now you're adding ­­ if there's a question that involves a substantial integrity ­­ a substantial question involving the integrity of the office? So that's an added ­­

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: In ­­ in that case ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: That's an added factor in your analysis?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: No. I think that in my analysis it's ­­ it's an issue that relates directly to the decision that's being made by the prosecutor ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: So I'm ­­ I guess I'm ­­

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: ­­ to their personal involvement.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: I guess I'm a little bit unclear as to what you're arguing. I mean, one rule could be did the judge have some significant involvement in a critical trial decision as a lawyer. Is that your rule, or are you adding something to that rule?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: That would be, I think, a ­­ a rule consistent with this Court's ruling in Murchison that you can't have ­­ that a fair trial in a free society does not allow the prosecutor who prefers the charges to become the judge of that. But I don't think that's a rule you necessarily have to reach in this case. Caperton tells us to look at all of the circumstances of the case. And that's what I'm suggesting we do here: We look at all of the circumstances. And ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: I ­­ I still don't see how the Brady violation fits into the formula you want us to adopt, unless you're amending it to say anything that involves the integrity of the office while you were the head of the office.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: I think more importantly, Justice Kennedy, that the Brady violation fits in because that is how the trial prosecutor carried out the decision that Chief Justice Castille had made. And so her conduct in carrying out that decision has a direct relationship to the issue itself.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: We don't have a Brady issue before us. The only issue is the recusal, right?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: That's correct.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: So we don't have ­­ the merits of the Brady issue are not in the case. But even the question that you're raising, you have prior opportunities to do that. You didn't raise it when there were prior post­conviction applications. So why aren't you precluding?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: That we didn't raise the recusal issue? Is that what you're asking me ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: ­­ Your Honor? In the prior post­conviction litigation, we didn't have the information that we have at this time, and that's the two critical pieces of evidence of information here. One is the memorandum that authorized the death sentence that showed the kinds of factors District Attorney Castille looked at in making that decision and showed that it was he who made that decision. We didn't have that before. The second factor would be the fact that it was a Brady issue, and that there had been evidence that had been suppressed and findings by a lower court judge that the prosecutor had done so willfully. So it was those two factors that were new to the case that caused us to file the recusal motion.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: There is a concern about sandbagging, though. I mean, if you do have a case where somebody has that information, I think the best thing to do would be to, you know, put it in a ­­ the back drawer, take your chances on ­­ on getting an acquittal. And if you don't, then you say, aha, the judge could have recused him or herself, and our ­­ our remedy is we get to go back and do it all again.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: I recognize the Court's concern of sandbagging. It's similar to the concern the Court expressed in Strickland in ineffectiveness cases, that lawyers would ­­ would try to create error so that they could give a open door or back door to the defendant on appeal. I think that we've seen that judges across the States have been diligent in protecting against sandbagging.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Well, Strickland's very different. I mean, you may think it's pretty unlikely that attorneys are going to deliberately commit error so that they have a later problem. But it's another thing if you're talking about a fact about the judge's prior involvement.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: I'm not sure I can agree with you, Your Honor, that it's unlikely. I've had that argument raised many times during the course of my practice. But even ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Not against you.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: Not against me.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: But even if it is unlikely, I think sandbagging, for whatever concern, can be addressed by the lower courts and certainly isn't a reason to narrow or not apply a due process analysis.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Well, I guess it's not a case of sandbagging, but it's somehow related in that the information you're talking about would have been information that seriously undermined the defense your client was presenting. In other words, the information goes to the nature of a prior relationship. And his whole argument and defense was, I didn't know, you know, who this person was. I had no contact with him at all. So, you know, in what sense does that ­­ the material that you're complaining about now is the last thing he would want to have come ­­ come out at his trial.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: In at least two different senses, I think. One is, is if this material were produced before trial. Before Mr. Williams testified, before he chose what defense he would present, perhaps counsel who only met Mr. Williams the day before trial would have had the opportunity to talk to him about this evidence and ­­ and counsel him and confer with him of what would be appropriate. My second part of the answer would be ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Is that ­­ well, just so I understand, you're saying the evidence might have been sufficient to persuade him not to lie?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: Might have been sufficient for counsel to be able to develop the ­­ the understanding with the defendant about what facts were important and what wasn't, and what might be a better defense than the defense this 19­year­old ­­ this 19­year­old young man with little counseling hoped to present. But ­­ but I would say even more is ­­ is the materiality in this case goes to sentencing. And there are many examples of capital cases where ­­ in evidence where a defense of not guilty was offered at trial.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: Counsel, am I correct that Mr. Draper, his accomplice, did not come forward until later? So he didn't know that the accomplice would say that there was a different story to tell at all, correct?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: That's correct. He did not know that prior.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: And he did not know that the sexual abuse could form a very potent defense to a death penalty because there was independent proof of it.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: For sentencing purposes, yes. And ­­ and the ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: The prosecutor, in fact, told the trial judge that there wasn't any independent evidence of sexual abuse by this man of other people, correct?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: Correct.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: And in fact, the records show there was.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: Correct.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: The independent evidence you're complaining about involved the defendant himself, correct?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: No. The independent ­­ well, let me step back. The ­­ the testimony from Marc Draper related to the defendant himself. The documents that were found within the prosecutor's file related to conduct between the deceased and other young men.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: What do you do with the fact that Chief Justice Castille was not solely responsible for the decision in this case? This was a decision by the Pennsylvania Supreme Court. Now, you say it was structural error. Suppose that the court had been divided and Chief Justice Castille voted to affirm the decision of the lower court. Would that decision still be invalid on the ground that he shouldn't have been participating?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: It might be. There would still be a taint to the decision­making process, but perhaps in that one narrow instance where he voted in the defendant's favor anyway. But even there, we don't know.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: Doesn't that mean it's not structural error?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: I don't ­­ I don't think so because even there we don't know what his role within the decision­making process. Perhaps it was a case where he already saw a majority, he had already persuaded a majority of the judges ­­ justices to vote in his favor and so ­­ to vote against it and then he thought his vote was ­­ was a vote that he could make without injecting this issue. The problem is that ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: So he might have persuaded a majority to vote to reverse, and then he turned around and he wrote an opinion saying that there should be an affirmance.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: The problem is we don't know what happened within the decision­making structure, and we can't know what happened within the decision­making structure. And that's why the rules should be that ­­ that a defendant should be entitled, anyone should be entitled to a panel of appellate judges where there are no judges with bias.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: If we agree with you, doesn't that lead inevitably to the rule that a majority of the judges on a multi­judge panel have the authority to require the recusal of a colleague?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: I ­­ that's an interesting question.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: And I think it would depend upon the rules of each court. I don't think due process requires that there be any kind of review by some greater panel or ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: Well, wouldn't they ­­ wouldn't that have to be the consequences? Suppose that ­­ suppose you make a recusal motion. You want Chief Justice Castille recused, and the other justices on the Pennsylvania Supreme Court say we think that he should be recused, and we're afraid that if we go ahead with this decision with his participation, the decision is going to be subject to attack down the road. And we can't allow that to happen, so we're going to require him to be recused in order to prevent him from tainting our decision­making process or creating at least the appearance that the decision­making process is tainted. So that would have to be a consequence of your rule, would it not?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: Not necessarily. The ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: They could just take their chances.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: Or the consequence of the rule could be that they informally go to the justice.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: And he says, no, I disagree with you.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: If ­­ if the rule in the State court ­­ if the rule of the court is that the ultimate decision lies with the justice, then that's the rule. And they ­­ and they take the chances because that's the rule that the courts adopted, and that's a perfectly appropriate and fine rule.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: There's something ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: What's awfully difficult in this case is not your case for me. It's not your case. It's the hundreds ­­ or not hundreds ­­ but look at all the briefs filed. There ­­ there are disqualification rules all over the law, and suddenly to turn this into a constitutional matter as we did in Caperton, which we did with our eyes open, we don't know what we're getting into. I mean, there are congressmen who can become judges who voted on statutes that come before them, as Justice Black did. There are executive branch officials who decide all kinds of things, and later on, something with their name signed on it comes up. When does the Constitution require it or not? So that's why I think you're getting these questions. My question is: Is there a way of avoiding this? And ­­ and the ­­ the thing that is suggested by ­­ by the other side is that you did ask for reconsideration. Reconsideration would have taken place without the chief justice because he had retired. Reconsideration can be pretty perfunctory, or it might be serious and thorough. Is there anything ­­ is there a way for us to send this back and say, you said you reconsidered it; we're not certain what that reconsideration consists of; reconsider it.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: I mean, is there a way to do that, and what do you think of that? That's what they're suggesting.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: Let ­­ there's a lot of ­­ of questions that fit in there. So let me try to start. The ­­ in my view, the Pennsylvania Supreme Court did not reconsider this case because they denied the motion for reconsideration. Had they granted the motion for reconsideration and then said we'll take another look at this without Chief Justice Castille, that's the remedy that we ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Can we tell them to do that?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: That's the remedy that we're asking for.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: So ­­ so we could say, given all the facts, of which there are quite a few, and the filing of a motion for reconsideration, and the fact that they may not have done it, go reconsider it, period. End of ­­ end of opinion. Can we do that?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: I would simply phrase it slightly differently, and ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: That's what I was hoping.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: And ­­ and say what we're not asking for is to reconsider the decision that's already been made. What we're asking for is to go back into the position before the error was committed and hear the case fresh.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: Well, do they have to hear ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: Can we do that ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: Excuse me.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: ­­ without holding that there was a dupe ­­ a constitutional violation? What would be our authority to require them to do it over again?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: It would have to be because there's a constitutional violation.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: There's something unsatisfying about the remedy that you're requesting, right? Because if the idea is that one judge can affect a whole panel, which seems right to me, but presumably that effect doesn't go away the moment that we send it back and they have to deal with it again, so aren't ­­ don't they continue to be tainted in some way?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: You face that same issue in ­­ in the Caperton case and the Lavoie case in ­­ and ­­ and granted the relief of sending it back for a new appeal. That may be there, and it may be that ­­ that the remaining justices who heard the case ­­ and the Pennsylvania Supreme Court is constituted differently, should it go back. There were three new justices elected this last November and took office in January. So the remaining justices may have to consider whether or not they can put aside the prior proceedings and start from fresh, or whether they're tainted. And we do that all the time. Whenever a case is reversed and sent back to a lower court judge, or that judge has to make a decision to look at this case in light of the guidance they've gotten from the higher court, then I trust that the judges will be able to look at themselves and do that.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: But there's one big difference between, I think, what Justice Breyer was suggesting and I think what you're asking. You wouldn't be satisfied if what the ­­ what the Pennsylvania Supreme Court was asked to do was simply to rule, again, on the matter of rehearing. You want a de novo appellate review; isn't that right?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: That's correct.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: What is the standard on rehearing? Is ­­ is ­­ it must be a very different standard, isn't it?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: It's compelling circumstances. And the ­­ the examples that are given in the commentary to the rule are things like a "known and obvious mistake of fact" or "mistake of law." But it's a narrow remedy, rarely granted, of compelling circumstances. And that's not what we're asking for. We're asking for a fresh start.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Counsel, I ­­ I understand your ­­ the first two of your three points, but I don't understand how the third works. This is ­­ you're concerned that the ­­ the Chief Justice cited his record with respect to capital cases in campaigning for office. I ­­ that certainly wouldn't be a ­­ a recusal issue without the other two points, right?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: That's correct.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Okay. So how does that have anything to do with the argument in this case?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: Our concern for that is that as ­­ as a candidate, Chief Justice Castille was reported to have said on multiple occasions, I sent 45 people to death row. By saying that, he's taking the personal responsibility for those decisions and for those actions that I think reflect ­­ become an additional circumstance that reflect upon the two other circumstances we've been discussing, his decision making and ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: It's an evidentiary point for you. It's not an independent ground for recusal.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: Absolutely. It's an added weight to the pile. But by itself, it would not be a due process violation.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: What weight, if any, do you think we should give to the current moratorium in Pennsylvania on the death penalty?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: The moratorium is really not particularly relevant to the question that's before the Court, and ­­ and not ­­ weight should not be given to it. The moratorium is simply the Governor's action of delaying executions in Pennsylvania. And in ­­ in Pennsylvania, the Governor has no power of ­­ of commutation by himself. Without having a unanimous recommendation from a Board of Parole, he can't reduce sentencing. His only power is to grant reprieve in individual cases, and he's done that for Mr. Williams to delay execution pending the receipt of a report from the legislature and possible action for it.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: When was the last time a prisoner was executed in Pennsylvania, other than those instances in which the prisoner decided that he did not want to pursue appellate remedies?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: The ­­ the three executions in Pennsylvania since the passage of the new statute in 1978 were all ­­ were all cases of prisoners who gave up their rights. I think the last contested execution was sometime in the early 1960s.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: So what's at issue here is only the death penalty, not the conviction itself, correct?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: That's right.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: And nobody has ­­ nobody other than these so­called volunteers has been convicted since 1978 ­­ has been executed since 1978?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: That's right. But Mr. Williams remains on death row. He remains in solitary confinement, and subject to the strict limitations of death row. If I may, Mr. Chief Justice, I'll reserve my time.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Eisenberg.

completeLines.speaker: EISENBERG
completeLines.speech: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: Petitioner argues that it is Judge Castille's supposed direct and personal and substantial involvement with this case that creates the constitutional due process recusal obligation. But as he has said here today, such direct involvement in the case is actually not necessary to his argument at all. He has said that if the D.A. merely promulgated a policy in favor of the death penalty and opposing the death penalty in every case without any involvement in the individual case, that that would still be a violation of the due process clause. And I ­­ I think that very fundamental ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: What do you think of our jurisprudence that says you can't be judge ­­ you can't be prosecutor and judge. And so I'm ­­ I'm ­­ what does it mean to be a prosecutor, if you're not taking responsibility personally, as he claimed during the election, for the decision to execute someone, whether by policy or by individual review? And there was clearly individual review here. At ­­ at what point do we give meaning to the constitutional command that you can't be prosecutor and judge? I know there's so many different kinds of recusals. This is the ideal case for someone to make a due process claim, because the judge here actually signed his name to his review of the facts and his decision to seek the death penalty. What ­­ as I'm looking at most of the ethical codes, most of the ethical codes would have said you get off if you made this decision.

completeLines.speaker: EISENBERG

And, in fact, the Court followed the practice of looking at it in the previous case ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: One thing is look at it. What triggers the look? That is, is the defendant permitted to say I want the judges who did not participate to make this decision?

completeLines.speaker: EISENBERG
completeLines.speech: Yes, Your Honor.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: So ­­

completeLines.speaker: EISENBERG
completeLines.speech: And counsel did so in a prior case only several years ago. They filed a motion for reconsideration. Justice Castille recused himself on that motion, and the full court went on to decide it. Under the IOPs, motions for reconsideration go to the individual justice, not to the Chief Justice. So if Petitioner's theory were correct, Justice Castille could have blocked that reconsideration. He did not. He recused himself and passed it on to the rest of the court. When, under the IOPs, a matter is assigned to an individual justice on the Pennsylvania Supreme Court, a full court matter is assigned to an individual justice. Section 2 of the IOP states explicitly that the assignment neither enhances the power of the assigned judge nor diminishes the power of the other Justices ensured to proper disposition.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: All right. That's really wonderful. And how about if they got it wrong?

completeLines.speaker: EISENBERG
completeLines.speech: They were never ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: Meaning ­­ it doesn't mean that if a whole court looks at something, it's got it right.

completeLines.speaker: EISENBERG
completeLines.speech: Of course, it ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: If there's an ethical standard that says the judge who's been involved in a case shouldn't be there, then they got it wrong on their own rules. If ­­ if there's a constitutional standard, it doesn't mean they were right, either. They got it wrong if they let him sit.

completeLines.speaker: EISENBERG
completeLines.speech: Yes, Your Honor, but they still face a dilemma, because they have to make a decision about whether the ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: But they have to do it no matter what, meaning if ­­ if the State is telling them look at this, and recuse someone if it's appropriate to do so, then the State has imposed that obligation on them.

completeLines.speaker: EISENBERG
completeLines.speech: Well, the question is whether the Constitution imposes the obligation for the full court to look at. And, in fact, in his recusal ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: Nothing about a decision in this case would require that. That's ­­

completeLines.speaker: EISENBERG
completeLines.speech: In ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: That's a feature unique to Pennsylvania. In many other States, including this Court, it goes up to the individual judge.

completeLines.speaker: EISENBERG
completeLines.speech: In his recusal motion, Your Honor, at page 200 in the Joint Appendix ­­ I'm sorry, at page 202 in the Joint Appendix, you'll see that the Petitioner made exactly this argument. He said, "Indeed, due process requires" ­­ emphasis in the original ­­ "requires that the full court decide due process­based recusal claims." And I think on Petitioner's theory, that would be true because it's a constitutional issue, and the failure to decide it potentially taints the rest of the court so that the action of the entire court is automatically invalid. And that's, I think, not what due process requires, because at the appellate level, the process is not the individual judge, it's the court. And the recusal or nonrecusal of an individual judge does not in and of itself automatically result in a deprivation of due process, because he is not the process. The court is the process. And you look at a variety of circumstances to decide whether the other members of the court ­­ under an objective standard, you can't know what they are doing subjectively, of course. But on the same objective standards applied in Caperton, to determine whether there is a probability of actual bias on the part of the other members of the court, whether it's a court of three, or a court as some en banc courts can be, a court of 15. Under the Petitioner's view, even the 15­to­nothing vote would be automatically, constitutionally invalid. And we don't think that that's ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: But if ­­ if we say that, then we say that being a judge on a 15­judge court doesn't really make much difference. You ­­ you don't have a duty, and you don't have an obligation. You can't persuade your colleagues. It's very hard for us to write that kind of decision.

completeLines.speaker: EISENBERG
completeLines.speech: May I, Your Honor? Your Honor, I think the answer is what the Pennsylvania Supreme Court states in its Section 2 of its IOPs. On every court of every size, it is the duty of each individual justice to make an independent determination following his oath to do the right thing, and that is why the court is not automatically invalid. Thank you.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Lev, four minutes remaining.

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: Thank you. Let's start with the passage of time. In our view, the passage of time isn't the relevant factor. It's that it's the same case. This is ­­ even though this case has lasted a very, very long time through numerous different hearings and delays, this is the same case. And so what you had was Chief Justice Castille participating in this case as both the prosecutor and a judge in the same case. And that's where the problem ­­ that's where the due process problem starts. What separates this out from the ethical rules is that this is an extreme and rare case. That's what Caperton was talking about, where the ethical rules were not sufficient to cover the problems here. And we know that this is an extreme and rare case because there's no other case like it, right? There's no other case that Respondents have cited to, and none that we found, where a judge in this situation has sat and decided on the case.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: Well, this may be an extreme case, but if we do not say any personal participation requires recusal under the Constitution, what other clear line can you give us?

completeLines.speaker: LEV
completeLines.speech: Well, to the extent that Caperton is not a clear line, I think we're ­­ we're still with Caperton. If you want to clarify the line of Caperton, it is about the ­­ the judge's participation in a significant decision­making in the case. And where the issues before them are related to that decision­making, that's ­­ that's the line I would suggest that you can draw in this case. On ­­ on question two, if you accept the Respondent's position, what you would be saying is it's okay to have one ­­ one biased judge on an appellate panel, or two, or three, so long as a majority voted in favor were not biased. And that's not appropriate under the Due Process Clause, the idea of fairness, the public confidence in the integrity of the fairness of the system requires that each judge be free from bias. And lastly, I would say about referring to the full court, we did that. We asked, if you look at our motion to recuse that's in the Joint Appendix, I think at Section 4 of our motion says if Judge Castille denies this, we ask that the full court hear it. And Justice Castille, using his power as the Chief Justice, blocked that. He said, I'm going to deny the motion to recuse, and I'm going to deny referral to the full court. So we did what we could to have the full court hear it, and we weren't able to get that. Thank you very much.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
